entry.title: Exploring open data quality
entry.summary: To contribute to discussions around open data quality, the ODI has been working with [Experian](https://directory.theodi.org/members/AQ1298ST) to investigate quality in several UK Government open datasets. Here, ODI Associate Leigh Dodds introduces the project and its initial findings

entry.summary: Better data can lead to better outcomes. But what do we mean by 'data quality'? ODI Associate Leigh Dodds, who is working with ODI Partner [Experian](https://directory.theodi.org/members/AQ1298ST) to explore data quality in UK open datasets, explains

entry.title: Building best practices for sharing public sector data
entry.summary: ODI Associate Leigh Dodds looks at how the Share-PSI 2.0 project is collecting and sharing best practices around the publication of public sector information, a useful resource for anyone leading or contributing to an open data initiative

entry.title: How to open your data in six easy steps
entry.summary: Do you have a raft of useful data you’re ready to open up for others to make use of, but don’t know where to start? Organisations like [Arup](http://theodi.org/open-enterprise-big-business-case-study-arup) and [Thomson Reuters](http://theodi.org/open-enterprise-big-business-case-study-thomson-reuters) have discovered huge benefits in opening their data, but it can be a daunting task. ODI Associate Leigh Dodds has broken down the process into six easy steps.

entry.title: Caution: data, use responsibly
entry.summary: Should open data be published with guidelines on its use and limits? Senior Consultant Leigh Dodds thinks so, and draws on Open Prescribing to explain why

entry.title: Take your first steps with Open Data Pathway
entry.summary: We're launching a new tool today called [Open Data Pathway](http://pathway.theodi.org). It's a self-assessment tool that will help you assess how well your organisation publishes and consumes open data, and identify actions for improvement.

entry.title: 5 ways to be a better open data reuser
entry.summary: Open data is still in its infancy. The focus so far has been on encouraging and supporting owners of data to publish it openly. A lot has been written about why opening up data is valuable, [how to build business cases](http://theodi.org/guides/how-make-business-case-open-data) for open data sharing, and [how to publish data](http://theodi.org/guides/engaging-reusers) in order to make it easy for people to reuse.

entry.title: Comparing the 5-star scheme with Open Data Certificates
entry.summary: I’ve been asked several times recently about the differences between [the 5-star scheme](http://5stardata.info/) for open data and the [Open Data Certificates](http://certificates.theodi.org/). How do the two ratings relate to one another, if at all? In this blog post I aim to answer that question.

entry.title: Simplifying the UK open data licensing landscape
Public draft of the open data maturity model
entry.summary: In partnership with the [Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (Defra)](https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/department-for-environment-food-rural-affairs "Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (Defra)"), the ODI has been developing a maturity model to help assess how effective organisations are at publishing and consuming open data.

entry.title: Why we can't use your "open" data
entry.summary: The decision about which licence to use is one of the most important steps in publishing an open dataset.

entry.title: Developing an open data maturity model
entry.summary: Organisational change is an important aspect of becoming an open data publisher. Often the technical process of getting data published is actually the easiest step. But if users are to have reliable, ongoing access to data then organisations need to consider the strategic, financial and operational impacts of making their open data publishing efforts sustainable.

entry.title: Research: investigation into publishing open election data
entry.summary: A number of people at the ODI have recently been looking at the topic of open election data, asking how election results could be collected, reported and analysed in order to increase transparency and drive democratic engagement.

entry.title: Publishing Open Statistical Data
Introducing CSVLint
entry.summary: The ODI tech team has recently been building a tool to validate CSV files. While CSV is a very simple format, it is surprisingly easy to create files that are hard for others to use.

entry.title: Tools For Working with CSV Files
entry.summary: Anyone working with open data for any length of time will have inevitably spent a long time wrangling CSV files to tidy, extract and reformat data.

entry.title: CC 4.0 and Open Data
entry.summary: After a lengthy two year development process the Creative Commons recently [announced the publication of their Version 4.0 licences](https://creativecommons.org/weblog/entry/40768). The new licences include a raft of changes based on lessons learned through application of the Creative Commons licences around the world.

entry.title: The Proliferation of Open Government Licences
entry.summary: As part of my work exploring [compatibility between open data licences](http://theodi.org/blog/exploring-compatibility-between-data-licences), I recently began looking at licences for government and public sector data. I was a little surprised to discover quite how many different licences and licence variants have been created.

entry.title: Machine Readable Rights Statements
entry.summary: As the open data movement continues to mature, discussion is focusing on how the publishing and use of open data can be become more sustainable. This includes making the process of opening up data clear and simple for any organisation.
